messageBody:
I am not sure when to use interfaces in the context of unit testing
(I haven't actually implemented any unit tests yet, still figuring
out how to refactor a design to best support unit testing).

Given a class Foo for which I want to create a mock object:

public class Foo {
public void doSomething() {
...
}
}

What is the better approach? To define an interface that only the
mock object and the original object implement or to subclass Foo?

interface:

public interface Foo {
void doSomething();
}

public class FooImpl implements Foo {
public void doSomething() {
...
}
}

public class MockFoo implements Foo {
public void doSomething() {
...
}
}

or subclassing:


public class Foo {
public void doSomething() {
...
}
}

public class MockFoo extends Foo {
public void doSomething() {
...
}
}


I don't see a reason to to use an interface if it is only going to be
implemented once (not counting the mock object, I can achieve the
same overriding methods). Am I missing something? Or is it "good
design" to specify the contract of a class with an interface even if
there is not going to be more than one implementation ever?

I would appreciate any insight into this matter.

Thank you,

Florian Brugger
